title: 111_hr44
content:
The Guam World War II Loyalty Recognition Act recognizes the suffering and loyalty of Guam residents through payments for claims, adjudication, and a grants program for memorials. The Guam World War II Loyalty Recognition Act acknowledges the suffering and loyalty of Guam residents during the occupation by Imperial Japanese forces in World War II. Residents endured death, rape, forced labor, and internment, while demonstrating unwavering loyalty to the United States. The Guam World War II Loyalty Recognition Act acknowledges the suffering and loyalty of Guam residents during the occupation by Imperial Japanese forces in World War II, including death, rape, forced labor, and internment. The act includes provisions for payments for Guam World War II claims. The Guam World War II Loyalty Recognition Act provides payments for Guam victims who suffered injuries during the occupation by Imperial Japanese forces. Compensation amounts range from $15,000 for specific injuries to $10,000 for others. The Guam World War II Loyalty Recognition Act provides compensation for Guam victims who suffered injuries during the occupation by Imperial Japanese forces. Payments range from $15,000 for specific injuries to $10,000 for others. Additionally, survivors of deceased residents and victims are eligible for payments of $25,000 and $7,000 respectively, distributed according to specified guidelines. Payments to eligible survivors of compensable Guam decedents or victims are distributed based on specific guidelines:
- If there is a living spouse but no child, the full payment goes to the spouse.
- If there is a living spouse and one or more children, half of the payment goes to the spouse and the other half to the child(ren).
- If there is no living spouse but one or more children, the full payment goes to the child(ren).
- If there is no living spouse or child but living parent(s), the payment is made to the parent(s). For compensable Guam decedents, payments are distributed to eligible survivors based on specific guidelines. If there is a living parent, all payment goes to the parent(s). If there is no living spouse, child, or parent, no payment is made. The term "compensable Guam decedent" refers to an individual who was a resident of Guam and died as a result of the attack and occupation of Guam during World War II. The term "compensable Guam victim" refers to individuals who suffered severe personal injuries or forced labor during the attack and occupation of Guam by Imperial Japanese forces in World War II. The Foreign Claims Settlement Commission determines eligibility for compensation based on specific criteria. The Foreign Claims Settlement Commission will establish regulations to define severe personal injuries or personal injuries for compensation purposes. The Foreign Claims Settlement Commission will establish regulations to define severe personal injuries or personal injuries for compensation purposes. SEC. 4. ADJUDICATION. The Foreign Claims Settlement Commission has the authority to adjudicate claims and determine eligibility for payments under section 3. The chairman will establish necessary rules and regulations for the Commission to carry out its functions, which will be published in the Federal Register. Claims must be submitted in a specific manner for the Commission to determine eligibility for payments under section 3. The Foreign Claims Settlement Commission specifies the manner and form for filing claims for payment under section 3. Claims must be filed within one year of public notice in the Federal Register. Adjudicatory decisions are made by majority vote and must be in writing with reasons stated. The Foreign Claims Settlement Commission makes adjudicatory decisions by majority vote in writing, stating reasons for approval or denial of claims. Approved payments will specify the amount awarded and any distribution. Deductions may be made for previous payments under the Guam Meritorious Claims Act of 1945. No interest is paid on awarded payments, and remuneration for representational services cannot exceed one percent of the total amount paid. After a claim is approved by the Foreign Claims Settlement Commission, any remuneration exceeding the maximum allowed by law is unlawful. Violators may face fines or imprisonment. Appeals of Commission decisions are final and not subject to further review. The Commission chairman certifies approved claims to the Secretary of the Treasury for payment. The Foreign Claims Settlement Commission certifies approved claims to the Secretary of the Treasury for payment under section 3. Claims accompanied by an affidavit attesting to all necessary facts establish eligibility without further documentation, including a detailed description of the injury or circumstance supporting the claim. Acceptance of payment under section 3 for a claim related to a compensable Guam decedent or victim satisfies all claims under the Guam Meritorious Claims Act of 1945 or this Act. Criminal penalties apply for false claims submitted under this subsection. The Secretary of the Interior will establish a grants program to honor the events of the occupation of Guam during World War II. Grants will be awarded for research, educational, and media activities to memorialize the loyalty of the people of Guam during the occupation. Applicants must submit a grant application to be eligible. Authorization of appropriations is also provided. Authorization of appropriations is provided for Guam World War II claims payments and adjudication, with $126,000,000 authorized for the Foreign Claims Settlement Commission. Additionally, $5,000,000 is authorized for the Guam World War II grants program.
